Award.AwardTitle: CSR: EAGER: Exploring Biological Network Robustness using Bio-Inspired Wireless Sensor Networks: A Novel Paradigm for Systems Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This project studies the design of robust bio-inspired Wireless Sensor Networks (B-WSN) by leveraging optimal results from nature?s computation. Functional robustness of living organisms is often attributed to the optimized structures of their gene regulatory networks (GRNs), which oversee the proper behavior of cells through interactions among different genes. GRNs can adapt to dynamic changes (i.e., perturbations) in the environment, and are resilient to the removal/malfunction of nodes in the network. This project will identify the features intrinsic to GRN based robustness and fault-tolerance and apply them to bio-inspired wireless sensor networks. In particular, teh project will devise suitable mapping between GRNs and WSNs to form the basis of our B-WSN testbed to assess network level robustness of biological systems. The B-WSN will be designed to act as an in silico testbed, where each node can be monitored and GRN-based routing topologies can be modiﬁed so that it is possible to demonstrate how speciﬁc topological aspects contribute to the robustness of complex systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding and designing control of complex dynamic systems remains a great challenge. Biology provides models to understand how such systems are controlled. But, why are biological systems robust? To answer this question, we have designed a robust bio-inspired Wireless Sensor Network (B-WSN) testbed, by leveraging the optimal structure of biological networks. Functional robustness of living organisms is often attributed to the optimized structures of their gene regulatory networks (GRNs), which oversee the proper behavior of cells through interactions among different genes. GRNs can adapt to dynamic changes (i.e., perturbations) in the environment, and are resilient to the removal/malfunction of nodes in the network. Recognizing that our B-WSN framework conceptually operates under similar (e.g., noisy and/or adverse) conditions as GRNs, we identified some of the topological features intrinsic to GRN based robustness and fault-tolerance in this project.

 

We proposed a novel mapping between GRNs and WSNs to form the basis of our B-WSN testbed to assess network level robustness of biological systems. The significant results accomplished in the project include: (i) applying graph theoretic metrics such as centrality to rank motifs based on their significance to robustness, and clustering to identify robustness hubs in the Bio-inspired WSN; (ii) support vector machine (SVM) and random forest regression models to study the correlations of motif patterns with network robustness; (iii) assessing the optimality of GRN topologies in terms of their signal transduction properties; (iv) estimating the capacity bounds of molecular feed forward loop circuits to understand their signal transduction characteristics; (v) designing efficient routing protocols in bio-inspired WSNs, and (vi) algorithms for predicting network growth based on the design principles of biological networks. Each of these solutions were validated through extensive performance evaluation using realistic sensor network simulations to demonstrate the high packet transmission robustness and data delivery ratio and low interference and energy consumption of our proposed framework under channel loss and node/link failures. This information will motivate the design of new WSN routing topologies and protocols that are resilient to network uncertainty, node breakdown and compromise. The project also developed innovative network-science based tools, and provides insights into the interplay of GRNs and WSNs that inspire new designs for engineered systems (i.e. fault-tolerant topologies for WSNs).

 

Additionally, the project findings were incorporated into the Parallel Programming course at VCU that the PI teaches regularly. The project findings were widely disseminated through several conference/journal papers. Finally, to foster further collaborations and excitement into this project, the PI co-founded the International Workshop on Complex Networks Dynamics: Cross-disciplinary tools for modeling, analysis and design (CoNed) which will be organized annually with a reputed conference and also the Emerging applications from Bio-Molecular Networks special track co-located with the BICT conference series.
